[Chewing the Scenery](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ChewingTheScenery): If the game had voice acting, Selphie would have been a [Large Ham](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LargeHam) as evidenced by the text changing pace and switching caps whenever she's amped up.
[Child Soldiers](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ChildSoldiers): Like the other SeeD cadets. She is seventeen years old when she finishes her training and becomes an active SeeD.
[Cloudcuckoolander](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Cloudcuckoolander): Obsessed with trains and maybe a little too eager to go for the violent solution....

[Combat Medic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CombatMedic): Selphie comes equipped with the most powerful healing spell of all (full cure) as part of her limit break as soon as you get her (and it's the most common unique spell you'll get through her random Slots Limit Break), and her unique abilities allow her to protect and heal the team. Or, you could just cast that triple Meteor her limit break just gave you, or use that magic stat and enviable accuracy to pummel her enemies with either magic attacks, Guardian Forces or plain ol' physical attacks.

[Communications Officer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CommunicationsOfficer): During the SeeD exam, Selphie is assigned to Squad A, the Comms Squad, and when you meet her, it's because she's been assigned to deliver a message to you, Seifer's nickname for her is even "Messenger girl". Not only that, Selphie is knowledgeable in communications technology, being an active blogger online.

[Confusion Fu](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ConfusionFu): The basis of her [Limit Break](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LimitBreak). You either get lucky and roll a [Triple Meteor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DiscOneNuke) or [The End](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OneHitKill) within three turns, or you end up getting yourself killed because nothing but [Pain](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/UselessUsefulSpell) and [Esuna](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MagicAntidote) pop up. (Unless, of course, you exploit the PS1 cheat.)

[Crash-Into Hello](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CrashIntoHello): How she met Squall. She smacked into him a short while before they had a mission together. He can give her a short tour of the Garden at this time.

[Cute and Psycho](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CuteAndPsycho): For all that she's a sweet little [Genki Girl](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GenkiGirl), she's also far and away the most violently [pragmatic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CombatPragmatist) of Squall's [True Companions](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TrueCompanions). Whenever she's involved in the planning phase of a mission, she always seems to suggest [using explosives](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/StuffBlowingUp). Also, when planning how to escape D-District, while a [Moomba](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RidiculouslyCuteCritter) is in the cell with everyone, she casually suggests skinning it and wearing it as a disguise. It's hard to tell if she was actually joking or not (she claims to be).

[The Determinator](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheDeterminator): Besides the dedication and hard work required to become a SeeD (being the only exchange student, the only Trabia student to graduate that year and only one of four graduates), Selphie simply will NOT stop until you're in her Garden Festival Committee. There's up to 3 different instances where she will try to recruit you, and that's before even leaving for your first SeeD mission. Not only that, but she collects old Timber Maniacs issues and tries to unravel the mystery behind the Laguna visions and who he is through her online blog.

[Chivalrous Pervert](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ChivalrousPervert): Zone is very protective of Rinoa despite being a [Lovable Sex Maniac](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LovableSexManiac).
[Heterosexual Life-Partners](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeterosexualLifePartners): They've known each other since childhood.

[La Résistance](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LaResistance): Members of the Forest Owls. The SeeDs are somewhat disturbed by their lack of organization and hasty attacks against the Galbadian Army, which often bring repercussions down on the Timber residents themselves.
[The Leader](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheLeader): Zone is the leader of the Forest Owls.
[Legacy Character](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LegacyCharacter): Their fathers were Forest Owls' founding members.
[Lovable Coward](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LovableCoward): They always have an excuse for not going into action.

[Master of Disguise](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MasterOfDisguise): They both disguise themselves before your party leaves Timber. Zone dresses as an old man, while Watts ended up [Dressing as the Enemy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DressingAsTheEnemy).
[Nice Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NiceGuy): Watts.
[Non-Action Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NonActionGuy): Both guys openly find convenient excuses for you to not select them at your party.
[Put on a Bus](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PutOnABus): After your party leaves Timber in the middle of Disc 1.
[Red Oni, Blue Oni](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RedOniBlueOni): Zone is red, while Watts is blue.
[Running Gag](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RunningGag): Zone's perpetual stomach ache.
[The Smart Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheSmartGuy): Watt's main duty in the Forest Owls is to collect information.
[Theme Naming](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThemeNaming): Named after TV signal and reception terms.
[Verbal Tic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VerbalTic): Watts has one, sir!
[You Killed My Father](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/YouKilledMyFather): Their reason for resenting President Deling.
[Asian and Nerdy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AsianAndNerdy): His appearance is very Japanese inspired.
[Bunny-Ears Lawyer](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BunnyEarsLawyer): Eccentric as he is, his thoughts are always valued.
[Chekhov's Gunman](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ChekhovsGunman): He's been mentioned by Rinoa near the end of Disc 1 but will only be revealed to be more relevant in Disc 3.
[Defeat Means Friendship](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DefeatMeansFriendship): Well, [he wasn't the one defeated](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NonActionGuy) but rather his guards.
[For Science!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ForScience): He is driven by his scientific curiosity rather than any morals.
[Funetik Aksent](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FunetikAksent): Thiz iz the vay he speaks.
[Heel–Face Turn](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeelFaceTurn): He was once Adel's follower, he joined  (SPOILER) Laguna  in overthrowing her.
[Mad Scientist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MadScientist): He is... very eccentric.

tropeName: Muggle with a Degree in Magic
tropeNotes: [Muggle with a Degree in Magic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MuggleWithADegreeInMagic): He isn't shown using magic at any point in the game, but he can create [machines that replicate supernatural abilities](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MagicFromTechnology), and his research led to the discovery of [para-magic](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/VancianMagic) and [Guardian Forces](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SummonMagic), making magic more accessible to people without the innate spellcating ability of sorceresses.

[Non-Action Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NonActionGuy): He is not combat proficient, even though he asks if Squall "vants to fisticuffs" and if he "vants to take it outside" when he gets angry at him.
[Real Men Wear Pink](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RealMenWearPink): His outfit.
[Shorter Means Smarter](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShorterMeansSmarter): He is the shortest character in the game and is touted as one of the smartest.

[Small Role, Big Impact](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SmallRoleBigImpact): Dr. Odine created the Junction system, played a role in the defeat of the tyrannical Adel, and will create the machine that will allow Ultimecia to send her consciousness to the present.
[The Smart Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheSmartGuy): Obviously, being a scientist and all.
[Third-Person Person](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ThirdPersonPerson): "There iz nothing Odine can't do". Or, "So what you will take Odine hostage? You are a fool!"
[Token Evil Teammate](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TokenEvilTeammate):  (SPOILER) Of the Adel resistance group .

[Actual Pacifist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ActualPacifist): They firmly disapprove of violence and those who resort to it. This isn't portrayed in an entirely positive light: had it not been for Squall and company's use of violence, they and their entire town would have been slaughtered. Squall can call him out on this, saying that he finds the principle admirable, but there are times when one must fight, and this gives Dobe something to think about.
[Brutal Honesty](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BrutalHonesty): They are much, *much* more blunt and straightforward than Squall, much to the latter's surprise and annoyance.
[Distaff Counterpart](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DistaffCounterpart): Flo is basically her husband in different gender.
[The Fettered](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheFettered): They will stick to their [Actual Pacifist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ActualPacifist) views no matter what.
[Grumpy Old Man](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GrumpyOldMan): Aside from their [Brutal Honesty](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BrutalHonesty) above, they're also very aloof. Though they do play cards with you.

[Jade-Colored Glasses](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JadeColoredGlasses): Dobe is a classic example of a [Wide-Eyed Idealist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/WideEyedIdealist) turned bitter by the politics of reality. Despite this they do retain at least some idealism, as Dobe claims he can negotiate with President Deling; when Squall informs him that Deling is dead and the sorceress is now in charge, Flo remarks "a sorceress is still a person."
[Jerkass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Jerkass): Their [Brutal Honesty](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BrutalHonesty) really gets in the main characters, even the also brutally honest Squall.
[The Leader](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheLeader): Of Fisherman's Horizon.
[Neutral Female](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NeutralFemale): Flo practices her [Actual Pacifist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ActualPacifist) views.
[Non-Action Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NonActionGuy): Dove practices his [Actual Pacifist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ActualPacifist) views.

[Obstructionist Pacifist](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ObstructionistPacifist): When Galbadian soldiers attack the town, Dobe tries to stop SeeD from fighting in its defence and goes to negotiate with the Galbadian captain. He has no idea how to respond when the captain tells him he's under orders to destroy the town, nor when Seed deifes his wishes and saves his life in the process.
[Pink Means Feminine](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PinkMeansFeminine): Flo wears a pink shirt.

[Satellite Love Interest](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/SatelliteLoveInterest): Flo is usually with Dobe. *Very briefly* inverted when it's Flo who approaches you alone and bluntly tells you it's your fault the Galbadians are there, before Dobe tells her she's wasting her breath.
[Amicably Divorced](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AmicablyDivorced): She and the Dollet pub owner are no longer together, but he still allows her to use his pub as her headquarters when she's in town.
[But Now I Must Go](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ButNowIMustGo): Everytime she acquires a rare card, she moves to another country.

[Chewing the Scenery](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ChewingTheScenery): She speaks very theatrically. If the game had voice acting, she would have been a [Large Ham](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LargeHam). The actress in Laguna's knight flashback uses her model, implying she may actually *be* an actress, justifying this even further.
[Everyone Calls Him "Barkeep"](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EveryoneCallsHimBarkeep): She's only addressed as the Queen of Cards.
[Failure Is the Only Option](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FailureIsTheOnlyOption): The player has to lose a number of rare cards to her in order to get new ones.

[Family Business](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FamilyBusiness): Her father is a painter and the one who makes the cards. Her ex-husband also runs a pub (and is [apparently](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InformedAbility) an avid card player himself) which she uses as her headquarters.
[I Let You Win](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ILetYouWin): In order to get more rare cards, as detailed in [Failure Is the Only Option](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FailureIsTheOnlyOption) above.

[Informed Ability](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InformedAbility): She boasts of her card skills, yet her gameplay and deck are no different from any other NPCs. [Come Disk 4, however...](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TookALevelInBadass)

[Took a Level in Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TookALevelInBadass): While her apparent card skills are an [Informed Ability](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/InformedAbility) initially, come Disc 4, if you face her at the escape pod in Esthar, she suddenly has the highest card-playing AI, every rule in the game, and if you didn't create new cards by losing specific rare cards to her during the game, she'll have all of them in her deck.

[Arrogant Kung-Fu Guy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ArrogantKungFuGuy): He's the only other gunblade user in Garden and has a pretty big ego in Dollet. In particular, he demands that *he* gets the kills [so that he can get the majority of the XP](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeKnowsAboutTimedHits).

[Ascended Fanboy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AscendedFanboy): The *Ultimania* guide reveals that he was influenced by seeing the movie in which Laguna played a knight, and that he based his gunblade stance on the one Laguna used during the film.
[Asskicking Leads to Leadership](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/AsskickingLeadsToLeadership):  (SPOILER) Becomes the Head of State to Galbadia from Disc 3 onwards.
[Badass Longcoat](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BadassLongcoat): Wears a grey coat with an emblem resembling the symbol of the Cross of Saint James on the sleeves.
[Boss Corridor](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BossCorridor): The last fight with Seifer and the fight with the Mobile Type 8 prior has two hallways before SeeD runs into them.

[Brainwashed and Crazy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BrainwashedAndCrazy): There is extensive fan debate as to how willingly Seifer served Edea as her Knight, but he certainly is this in the final battle with him, being used by Ultimecia. He even admits that he doesn't care, just wanting to impress [Squall](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheRival) and prove he was right.

[Break Them by Talking](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BreakThemByTalking): He tries to play on the party members' memories of their time with him (or in Irvine's case, the fact that he's from Galbadia Garden), and that Sorceress Edea is his and his fellow orphans' Matron. He ends up getting a party-wide [Shut Up, Hannibal!](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ShutUpHannibal), concluding with Squall calling Seifer just another enemy.

[Brought Down to Badass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BroughtDownToBadass): Most players will find Seifer a pushover if they spend enough time grinding and stacking magic for their Junctions. But put this into context: Seifer loses access to both the GFs and the Junction system upon his defection from Garden, which means he has been severely weakened and no longer has any way to artificially buff his capabilities. This doesn't stop him from still being deadly enough solo an entire Galbadian army unit or fight against the heroes in 3-against-1 confrontations, where he can easily kill an unprepared or underlevelled character in a single stroke. Lastly, Seifer was also able to learn how to draw and stock para-magic *without a GF and the Junction system* in a very short period of time after his [Face–Heel Turn](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FaceHeelTurn), something which none of the cast (not even Edea!) were able to pull off.
[The Bully](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheBully): Loves belittling people he dislikes or who are weaker than he is, and sometimes even acts out of line deliberately to piss them off.

[Can't Catch Up](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CantCatchUp): As a Garden student, he's fully equal to Squall or even a bit stronger, and Quistis mentions that they're both in a class of their own in strength and potential, as well as using gunblades. Problem is, after he leaves Garden, Seifer loses access to the Guardian Force and Junction resources that SeeD use, so Squall treats him like more of a [Goldfish Poop Gang](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoldfishPoopGang) and he can never come even close to the party's strength.
[Chewing the Scenery](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ChewingTheScenery): He can be quite theatrical.
[Child Soldiers](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ChildSoldiers): Like Squall, he's been at Garden since it was founded, which would have been when he was about six years old.

[Chuunibyou](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Chuunibyou): Downplayed but very much deconstructed. Seifer is VERY obsessed with idea of being a Sorceress' Knight, and it's seriously affected his humility (or lack thereof) and morality. It's *mostly* kept under control while as a Garden student, but once he actually gets to be in the service of A Sorceress, it spirals out of control, leading to his [Tautological Templar](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TautologicalTemplar) mindset below and his villainous deeds in general. If he was brainwashed, it's pretty clear [there was not that much needed in the first place](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MoreThanMindControl).
[Color-Coded for Your Convenience](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ColorCodedForYourConvenience): White to Squall's black.
[Cool Sword](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CoolSword): His gunblade, Hyperion.

[Creepy Crosses](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CreepyCrosses): He's distinguished by the Templar cross that he wears, which is used in his most powerful [Limit Break](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LimitBreak) as a portal to what looks like [Hell](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Hell).

[Cutscene Power to the Max](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CutscenePowerToTheMax): Unless you send your characters into battle with him without junctions, Seifer as a boss is unlikely to give you a lot of trouble. But during an automated sequence just before the final battle with him, he  (SPOILER) goes Odin on Odin by [reversing](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/CounterAttack) his [Zantetsuken](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OneHitKill) to *[vertically bisect](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HalfTheManHeUsedToBe)* him...***[with no effort at all](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheLawOfDiminishingDefensiveEffort)*** (In fairness, when Odin appears as a boss in the series, he generally lacks [Contractual Boss Immunity](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ContractualBossImmunity) to make up for his time limit).  Even Squall is shocked. Of course, this sets up the stage for  (SPOILER) the appearance of Gilgamesh  a few turns later, who proceeds to  (SPOILER) [utterly defeat him in your place](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheUnfought) .
[Delinquents](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Delinquents): Ironically, he's the head of the disciplinary committee.
[Determinator](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Determinator): Seifer simply does not back down. Even after you KO him.

[Didn't Think This Through](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DidntThinkThisThrough): His plan when he breaks into the TV studio isn't actually that different from Rinoa's train job—he just grabs Deling without considering what to do next or how to deal with the retribution from Galbadian security.

[Disc-One Final Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DiscOneFinalBoss): The last faceoff with Seifer concludes the third disc of play, and is also the game's [Point of No Return](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PointOfNoReturn), since a lot of stuff is blocked off on Disc 4.
[The Dragon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheDragon): To Ultimecia. He is her Knight and protector, leading Galbadia Garden, and later Galbadia in her name.

[Dual Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DualBoss): The third time he's fought, it's with Edea by his side. This isn't a full demonstration of the trope because he still fights alone; Edea cannot do anything and SeeD cannot affect her in any way until Seifer is sent to the floor.
[Duel Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/DuelBoss): The very first time Seifer is fought as a boss, it's him vs Squall alone. He doesn't take much to put down, and Squall mocks him for being a weak boss.

[Enemies List](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EnemiesList): He has his 'tough-nut-to-crack' list. You first hear about it early in the game when Quistis wishes him good luck after him telling her that he doesn't need luck and he tells his lackeys Fujin and Raijin to "add Instructor Trepe to the list!" It's later made more clear when he's subjecting Squall to [Electric Torture](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ElectricTorture) and says that he didn't think he'd talk easily.

[Establishing Character Moment](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EstablishingCharacterMoment): In the opening cutscene where he duels Squall, Seifer uses a one-handed style is that flashier than Squall's more practical two-handed stance, pauses in the middle of the duel to taunt him, and once Squall begins to overpower him Seifer busts out a Fire spell to stun him and then slash him in the face while he's getting up. This sets up him as an arrogant bully and show-off who has no problems playing dirty to beat his rival if he can't do it fairly.

[Evil Counterpart](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/EvilCounterpart): To Squall. Their designs also make this very obvious—Squall is brunet, Seifer is blond; Squall wears black, Seifer wears white; Squall has more feminine features, Seifer has a very strong jaw; and they have opposite scars.
[Face–Heel Turn](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FaceHeelTurn):  (SPOILER) Until the ending.

[Four Is Death](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FourIsDeath): Just like his Sorceress master, Seifer is fought as an enemy four times total; the last time doubles as the [Point of No Return](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PointOfNoReturn) for most of the game's sidequests.

[The Friend Nobody Likes](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/TheFriendNobodyLikes): He's a case of Seniority and Proximity, since while he's on the same side as the rest of the protagonists for the first disc, no one especially likes him. Even Fujin and Raijin eventually decide he's gone too far and stops helping him.

[Gangsta Style](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GangstaStyle): If you removed the "blade" part of his gunblade, this is exactly how he holds the "gun".  (SPOILER) [Justified](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JustifiedTrope) since he adopted his stance from an in-universe [B-Movie](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BMovie) where the actor (which happened to be Laguna) had *literally no idea* how to wield a gunblade and just followed [Rule of Cool](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RuleOfCool) .

[Good Scars, Evil Scars](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GoodScarsEvilScars): A subtle variation; the scar that Seifer acquires in the opening FMV *would* be a hero scar on its own, but it's a mirror-image inverse of Squall's, making it more of a villain scar in context.
[Guest-Star Party Member](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GuestStarPartyMember): He's briefly playable during the Dollet mission.
[He Knows About Timed Hits](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HeKnowsAboutTimedHits): He knows that the majority of the XP comes to the guy who makes the kill, which is why he wants to hog the kills.

[Hidden Depths](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HiddenDepths): Though he *is* a jerk and a bully, there's more to Seifer than just that. His references to a "[romantic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chivalric_romance) dream" and his preoccupation with the idea of being a Sorceress's Knight suggest that he aspires to being a heroic figure, an aspiration which Ultimecia plays upon to manipulate him into serving her. Rinoa talks about how he spent the previous summer working with her and the Timber Owls in their resistance against the Galbadian occupation of Timber, and how helpful and inspiring he was. Some of the dialog between Seifer and Squall during the field exam indicates an odd sense of respect between the two and suggests that, in his overly aggressive way, Seifer thinks he is helping Squall by challenging him. And, of course, the entire reason he breaks out of Garden and goes to Timber in time to be drawn in by Edea is because he thinks they've been sent into more danger than they're equipped for and will need help.
[Hot-Blooded](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/HotBlooded): He's really enthusiastic about the fighting in Dollet.

tropeName: I Just Want to Be Special
tropeNotes: [I Just Want to Be Special](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IJustWantToBeSpecial): What Seifer's ambitions to be a Knight essentially boils down to. His problematic and rebellious behavior at Balamb Garden is rooted in his desire to be respected by his peers. His antagonism towards Squall is [implied to be jealousy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/GreenEyedMonster) of Squall achieving just that.
[Impossibly Cool Weapon](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ImpossiblyCoolWeapon): His Hyperion gunblade.

[Improbable Weapon User](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/ImprobableWeaponUser): As with Squall, he uses a gunblade. *Unlike* him however, the grip is more of a traditional pistol one as opposed to the curved grip that Squall uses, meaning that Seifer's was likely even more difficult to master. It's harder to time the hit in gameplay too.

[I've Come Too Far](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/IveComeTooFar): In the last [Boss Battle](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BossBattle) against him, **everyone** from his foes to his closest friends, and himself, know that he is but a pawn for the [Big Bad](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigBad), and stands no chance, but he is too stubborn to call it quits.
[Jerkass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Jerkass): Though initially one that does think he's doing the right thing.
[Jerk Jock](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JerkJock): A [Big Man on Campus](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BigManOnCampus) belittling people he deems weak.
[Jumped at the Call](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JumpedAtTheCall): Unfortunately for him, it was the wrong call.

[Karma Houdini](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KarmaHoudini): He never pulls any sort of act of redemption, and yet he never has to face any real consequences for his actions. In the ending cinematic, he is seen fishing with Raijin and Fujin, while Balamb Garden flies by. To be fair, he was very clearly used and manipulated by the sorceress, possibly even to the point of mind control.

[Ki Manipulation](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KiManipulation): The manual says that the fire magic used in Seifer's [Limit Break](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LimitBreak) is produced by chi and not Para-Magic.
[Kick the Dog](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KickTheDog): Literally and figuratively.
[Lady and Knight](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LadyAndKnight): Dark Knight to Edea's  (SPOILER) and later Ultimecia's  Dark Lady.
[Light Is Not Good](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LightIsNotGood): Wears a long white trench coat. Also serves as one of the antagonists.
[Lightning Bruiser](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LightningBruiser): He's pretty fast for his physical size and moves just as swift and hard as the more wiry Squall in battle.
[More than Mind Control](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MoreThanMindControl): Seifer is somewhere between [Brainwashed and Crazy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BrainwashedAndCrazy) and this trope.

[Moveset Clone](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/MovesetClone): He has the same progression of [Limit Breaks](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LimitBreak) as Squall does, and the same "trigger" attack, but it requires different timing.
[Named Weapons](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NamedWeapons): Hyperion comes from [Greek Mythology](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Myth/ClassicalMythology).
[Never My Fault](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NeverMyFault): Admitting being wrong is clearly not his forte...

tropeName: Never Speak Ill of the Dead
tropeNotes: [Never Speak Ill of the Dead](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/NeverSpeakIllOfTheDead): When the party thinks he is dead, they remember him in a fonder light—much to the frustration of Squall who isn't willing to sugarcoat that Seifer was a bully and a [Jerkass](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/JerkAss).

[Out of Focus](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OutOfFocus): After Disc 2, his importance to the plot diminishes severely.  (SPOILER) That's because he spent most of Disk 3 trying to find and control the Lunatic Pandora, under orders from Ultimecia.

[Overshadowed by Awesome](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/OvershadowedByAwesome): He's a legitimately dangerous fighter in his own right, including being able to defeat Odin in a single blow and easily solo a unit of Galbadian soldiers. But he's no match for Squall, particularly when the latter's stacked to the nines with Guardian Forces and Junction.

[Pet the Dog](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PetTheDog): He has a few [Pet the Dog](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PetTheDog) moments when it comes to Rinoa...but his many [Kick the Dog](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/KickTheDog) moments tend to overshadow it...and we *never* see those moments since they occur before the game.
    - There's also one non-Rinoa moment: when Squall, Zell, and Selphie graduate as SeeDs, while he's clearly annoyed that he didn't graduate (and got scolded on top of that), Seifer takes the time to gather all those who didn't graduate and then give Squall and Zell a genuine, warm applause. Considering his [attitude](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/Jerkass), it comes off as this. But then he proceeds to kick a lot of dogs later. - He also leaves Garden unauthorized in order to help Squall and his group, since he considered they could wind up fighting the entire Galbadian Army. This good action on his part, though, leads to him being captured and brainwashed by Sorceress Edea.
[Playing with Fire](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PlayingWithFire): Loves fire magic almost as much as his gunblade, and even uses it as part of his [Limit Break](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/LimitBreak).

[Psychopathic Manchild](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/PsychopathicManchild): A type C case, In contrast to Squall, who is more emotionally withdrawn, Seifer is more emotionally stunted; incredibly impulsive, violent, and a bully that jumps at the chance to serve by Edea to fulfill his childhood dream.  (SPOILER) He ends up getting [Brainwashed and Crazy](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/BrainwashedAndCrazy) as a result.

[Recurring Boss](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/RecurringBoss): After his [Face–Heel Turn](/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FaceHeelTurn), Squall has to confront Seifer on deadly terms 4 times; the first of these is a duel, and the rest are all party boss fights. Seifer is virtually a pushover in these fights, something Squall lampshades the first time.
